summary: i’m still bitter that they killed bran’s direwolf so that jon is the only who has one. bran named his wolf summer for a reason,...

summary: Did Bran or Catelyn ever personally kill anyone?
question: Did Bran or Catelyn ever personally kill anyone?
answer:
Catelyn, yes. Aegon Frey at the Red Wedding, and before in AGoT:

Tyrion ducked under his sword, lashed out with the axe, the man reeled backward…and Catelyn Stark stepped up behind him and opened his throat.

- Tyrion IV, AGoT

Bran’s killed through Summer.

The direwolf had killed three of them, maybe more, but there had been too many. When they formed a tight ring around the tall earless man, he had tried to slip away through the rain, but one of their arrows had come flashing after him, and the sudden stab of pain had driven Bran out of the wolf’s skin and back into his own.

- Bran IV, ASoS

Depends if you think of that as personally killing someone or not.

reblog.comment:

Depends if you think of that as personally killing someone or not.

Depends if you think of that as personally killing someone or not.

summary: We all thought that Ned Stark was being overdramatic when Cat was like ‘Bran’s just a boy!’ and Ned’s like ‘HE WON’T BE A BOY...
body: We all thought that Ned Stark was being overdramatic when Cat was like ‘Bran’s just a boy!’ and Ned’s like ‘HE WON’T BE A BOY FOR LONG’ and it’s like, come on, dude, he’s eight years old, but clearly Ned just really knew his Stark family genetics because puberty absolutely hit Bran like a freight train just a few years later

summary: Who should survive to help sansa administering the North? I could see bran as her merlin and arya as her assassin/spy. How about...
question: Who should survive to help sansa administering the North? I could see bran as her merlin and arya as her assassin/spy. How about other characters?
answer: Honestly given how the North’s political system is structured, she would be expected to rule alone. However in the case where Bran doesn’t become king (something I’m 98% sure will happen in the books), I can see Sansa and Bran working as a duo. She handles the politics, he handles the North’s brand of justice. She handles trade (because she has ties to other kingdoms) while he meets with the Lords because he was great at dealing with them as a child in the books and so on. Sansa has weakness where Bran’s strengths lie and vice versa.

reblog.comment: Honestly given how the North’s political system is structured, she would be expected to rule alone. However in the case where Bran doesn’t become king (something I’m 98% sure will happen in the books), I can see Sansa and Bran working as a duo. She handles trade (because she has ties to other kingdoms) while he meets with the Lords because he was great at dealing with them as a child in the books and so on. Sansa has weakness where Bran’s strengths lie and vice versa.

She handles the politics, he handles the North’s brand of justice. She handles trade (because she has ties to other kingdoms) while he meets with the Lords because he was great at dealing with them as a child in the books and so on. Sansa has weakness where Bran’s strengths lie and vice versa.

Sansa has weakness where Bran’s strengths lie and vice versa.

summary: [E]ven though Summer and other companions are dead or otherwise occupied, Bran himself remains – though what remains of Bran is...
text: [E]ven though Summer and other companions are dead or otherwise occupied, Bran himself remains – though what remains of Bran is somewhat unclear. As the new Three-Eyed Raven, Bran’s connection with humanity feels thinner than ever. Ironically enough, he just might be humanity’s best hope for survival.
source: Josh Wigler in the Hollywood Reporter.

reblog.comment: Josh Wigler in the Hollywood Reporter.

summary: The final season of Game of Thrones will premiere on April 14, and it’s the end of an era. Here’s what we know so far about the...
body:
The final season of Game of Thrones will premiere on April 14, and it’s the end of an era. Here’s what we know so far about the season eight!

Image Source: Twitter

Along with everyone else in the world, we’re looking forward to the final season of Game of Thrones. It’s going to be six episodes of breathless action and a culmination of nine years of story-telling. It’s rare for a series to be able to have an endpoint in mind when they start, but that’s what Game of Thrones has done. Everything means something. If you rewatch, chances are you’ll find something new to support a theory you’re currently obsessing over.

Now, I said we’re looking forward to the final season, but when you translate that into what’s happening in our minds, it’s just a bunch of vowel sounds and flailing. We’re invested in this conclusion.

Over the last few weeks, HBO has released character portraits and the first trailer for the final season. I highly doubt we’ll get much more, but we can always hope.

To start things off, let’s take a look at the series of character portraits that HBO dropped on Twitter. Someone is definitely missing from these, *coughGendrycough*, but the internet has poured over them. One of the first things I noticed wasn’t the picture, but a certain sequence on EW’s Instagram of some of portraits.

If you click through, you’ll see Bran first, and on the next swipe, is the Night King.

Y’all, I know it’s a prevailing theory, but these portraits add something to that for me. From their posture to their placement. If Bran is the Night King, does that mean he went too far back and couldn’t return? Will there be a place in these final episodes where we see Bran make that jump when things get close during a battle?

This would also make sense in terms of the prophecy the Three-Eyed Raven told him:

“You will never walk again, but you will fly.”

This could be a nod to his warging and being the new Three-Eyed Raven, but I feel like he could mean that Bran as the Night King will fly Viserion this season. I’d be very surprised if the Night King had no connection to the Bran or the Stark family.

Another detail that stuck out to me was Sansa’s clothing.

We see her presumably hand over Winterfell to Daenerys when she arrives with Jon, but we all know Sansa well enough to know she’s not going all in just yet. No matter what Jon believes about this Targaryen. If you look closely at her clothing, though, it looks like dragon scales. I know she might not actually kill Drogon or Rhaegal, but the visual is enough.

You can take a look at all the portraits below as each character takes a seat on the Iron Throne.

Image Source: Twitter
Image Source: Twitter
Image Source: Twitter
Image Source: Twitter
Image Source: Twitter
Image Source: Twitter
Image Source: Twitter
Image Source: Twitter
Image Source: Twitter
Image Source: Twitter
Image Source: Twitter
Image Source: Twitter
Image Source: Twitter
Image Source: Twitter
Image Source: Twitter
Image Source: Twitter
Image Source: Twitter
Image Source: Twitter
Image Source: Twitter

 

In addition to the portraits, HBO also released the trailer. In it, Arya Stark is racing through the crypts of Winterfell, and she’s terrified. This is greatly at odds with her voiceover:

“I know Death. He’s got many faces. I look forward to seeing this one.”

Judging by the running, maybe it’s not a face she wants to see? Or maybe Arya is setting a trap much like she did for the Waif? All I know is Arya is holding a dragon glass dagger, and a few shots later we see Gendry walk beside a huge pile of dragon glass and his forge. I need this reunion like I need air.

Another important detail in the trailer, is we see Jon and Dany approach her remaining dragons. Could this mean we’ll see Jon Snow become a dragon rider this season?

A moment of relief is seeing Tormund and Beric Dondarrion safe after the fall of the Wall in season seven. Also in the trailer, there are several battle scenes from the Battle for Winterfell, along with the Unsullied awaiting battle. The Hound is surrounded by fire, and we see Cersei’s new warriors from Essos, the Golden Company arrive. Cersei herself looks sadden by something, and Jamie Lannister chooses his side once and for all:

“I promised to fight for the living. I intend to keep that promise.”

Our favorite Lannister, Tyrion, is only seen for a split second, though. It’s a shot we’ve seen before, of him looking up at the sky. Perhaps he’s watching Jon and Dany fly around Winterfell? What does this mean for the Hand of the Queen that we only see him for a brief moment?

Watch the trailer below and share your thoughts with us!

 

P.S. This gif gives me life. I’m pretending there’s not a sad ending here.

via GIPHY

 

Game of Thrones premieres Sunday, April 14, on HBO. Be sure to live tweet with us @WeSoNerdy!

‘Game of Thrones’ Season 8 Round-Up: Portraits, Trailers, and Theories! The final season of Game of Thrones will premiere on April 14, and it’s the end of an era. 802 more words

‘Game of Thrones’ Season 8 Round-Up: Portraits, Trailers, and Theories! The final season of Game of Thrones will premiere on April 14, and it’s the end of an era. 802 more words
trail.content:
The final season of Game of Thrones will premiere on April 14, and it’s the end of an era. Here’s what we know so far about the season eight!
External image

Image Source: Twitter

Along with everyone else in the world, we’re looking forward to the final season of Game of Thrones. It’s going to be six episodes of breathless action and a culmination of nine years of story-telling. It’s rare for a series to be able to have an endpoint in mind when they start, but that’s what Game of Thrones has done. Everything means something. If you rewatch, chances are you’ll find something new to support a theory you’re currently obsessing over.

Now, I said we’re looking forward to the final season, but when you translate that into what’s happening in our minds, it’s just a bunch of vowel sounds and flailing. We’re invested in this conclusion.

Over the last few weeks, HBO has released character portraits and the first trailer for the final season. I highly doubt we’ll get much more, but we can always hope.

To start things off, let’s take a look at the series of character portraits that HBO dropped on Twitter. Someone is definitely missing from these, *coughGendrycough*, but the internet has poured over them. One of the first things I noticed wasn’t the picture, but a certain sequence on EW’s Instagram of some of portraits.

If you click through, you’ll see Bran first, and on the next swipe, is the Night King.

Y’all, I know it’s a prevailing theory, but these portraits add something to that for me. From their posture to their placement. If Bran is the Night King, does that mean he went too far back and couldn’t return? Will there be a place in these final episodes where we see Bran make that jump when things get close during a battle?

This would also make sense in terms of the prophecy the Three-Eyed Raven told him:

“You will never walk again, but you will fly.”

This could be a nod to his warging and being the new Three-Eyed Raven, but I feel like he could mean that Bran as the Night King will fly Viserion this season. I’d be very surprised if the Night King had no connection to the Bran or the Stark family.

Another detail that stuck out to me was Sansa’s clothing.

We see her presumably hand over Winterfell to Daenerys when she arrives with Jon, but we all know Sansa well enough to know she’s not going all in just yet. No matter what Jon believes about this Targaryen. If you look closely at her clothing, though, it looks like dragon scales. I know she might not actually kill Drogon or Rhaegal, but the visual is enough.

You can take a look at all the portraits below as each character takes a seat on the Iron Throne.

External image

In addition to the portraits, HBO also released the trailer. In it, Arya Stark is racing through the crypts of Winterfell, and she’s terrified. This is greatly at odds with her voiceover:

“I know Death. He’s got many faces. I look forward to seeing this one.”

Judging by the running, maybe it’s not a face she wants to see? Or maybe Arya is setting a trap much like she did for the Waif? All I know is Arya is holding a dragon glass dagger, and a few shots later we see Gendry walk beside a huge pile of dragon glass and his forge. I need this reunion like I need air.

Another important detail in the trailer, is we see Jon and Dany approach her remaining dragons. Could this mean we’ll see Jon Snow become a dragon rider this season?

A moment of relief is seeing Tormund and Beric Dondarrion safe after the fall of the Wall in season seven. Also in the trailer, there are several battle scenes from the Battle for Winterfell, along with the Unsullied awaiting battle. The Hound is surrounded by fire, and we see Cersei’s new warriors from Essos, the Golden Company arrive. Cersei herself looks sadden by something, and Jamie Lannister chooses his side once and for all:

“I promised to fight for the living. I intend to keep that promise.”

Our favorite Lannister, Tyrion, is only seen for a split second, though. It’s a shot we’ve seen before, of him looking up at the sky. Perhaps he’s watching Jon and Dany fly around Winterfell? What does this mean for the Hand of the Queen that we only see him for a brief moment?

Watch the trailer below and share your thoughts with us!

 

P.S. This gif gives me life. I’m pretending there’s not a sad ending here.

via GIPHY

 

Game of Thrones premieres Sunday, April 14, on HBO. Be sure to live tweet with us @WeSoNerdy!

summary: Analisi e teorie - strampalate - sul trailer di Game of Thrones
title: Analisi e teorie - strampalate - sul trailer di Game of Thrones
body:
Analisi e teorie – strampalate – sul trailer di Game of Thrones

Lo abbiamo sognato, agognato e temuto ed eccolo finalmente.
Il primo trailer della stagione 8 di Game of Thrones è ufficialmente tra noi. Ed è una bomba.
E da quando è uscito ci sta facendo uscire fuori di testa con le teorie più assurde – Comunque Frittella è l’unico vero re, sapevatelo.
Ma torniamo a noi.
Fino ad ora avevamo avuto solo briciole, accenni di ciò che sarebbe accaduto, inframezzati…

summary: I believe that the Night King's target is Bran. He has already marked him and even on the previous season he was chasing him....
body: I believe that the Night King’s target is Bran. He has already marked him and even on the previous season he was chasing him. So, I’m afraid for the youngest Stark kid and I hope nothing bad will happen to him on this final season.
